The point is not to bash Friedman; it is, instead, that Friedman was pushing the doctrine of immaculate inflation — the idea that a rising money supply leads directly to inflation even if there's a lot of slack in the economy 2/

A forgotten moment in economic discourse: that multi-year period when Milton Friedman kept predicting runaway inflation even as price stability returned 1/ https://t.co/ljDq7fney3 https://t.co/dgGVQc1UwG
So while I'll be reading the details, everyone should chill out 5/

We'll also, no doubt, be hearing a lot about M2 growth and the hyperinflation it portends.  3/ https://t.co/7ABVgUYgsk

But if there's one thing we should have learned from the past 15 years, it is that short-run fluctuations in headline inflation say nothing about underlying forces. Core inflation, by various measures, is a much better guide 2/ https://t.co/qV8EEkRw8H

Moral of the story: when you get a data point that's at odds with other information, it might — might! — be a data issue, not a real economic issue. The April whiff might be real, it might be problems with seasonal adjustment or something else. Wait and see 3/
What we eventually learned was that it was a data artifact: hedonic indices for some imports were overdoing the quality adjustment. Actual import price behavior wasn't especially weird 2/

A reminiscence that may be relevant to the jobs number: Back in the late 1980s there was a big puzzle about US import prices. The dollar had fallen sharply, but import prices hadn't gone up. There were many, many papers trying to explain why 1/

RT @JustinWolfers: Looking through some old files I just stumbled across the tenure review I wrote a few years back for... Paul Krugman.

The real-world importance of this observation is that there's a lot of income way up there at the top. Which is why effectively taxing that income matters 3/

Roughly, the bottom 95% of incomes seem to fit a lognormal distribution pretty well. But the upper tail is much, much fatter than that would suggest; far more weight on extremely high incomes, fitting Pareto very well 2/

Nerd interest only: I got some comments from hard-science types about my log-log plot in Friday's newsletter illustrating the Pareto aspect of top income; they claimed that any distribution would look like that. But bottom 95% of inc dist doesn't: 1/ https://t.co/hfg1w4M3ZT

I keep seeing assertions that Biden is governing far to the left of where he campaigned. But has anyone looked back at the Democratic platform? Everything happening now was promised last year https://t.co/3dLbikQU9L https://t.co/u54p3gzAv6
So it was a weird moment in which a panicked GOP accepted a center-left agenda. And Biden is now building on that 5/

Those enhanced UI benefits, in particular — probably the single most important misery-reducer — were Ron Wyden's idea. Remember, also, that Trump officials kept floating useless proposals for corporate tax cuts 4/

When disaster struck, Rs literally had no idea what to do — if it doesn't involve tax cuts or punishing people, their minds are empty. Yet this was bad enough that even they realized that something had to happen. So they basically signed on to plans devised by Ds 3/
You may wonder how we managed to do so much big spending on people in need while Trump was in office. My take is that we were helped by the GOP's haplessness when it came to substance 2/

RT @nytopinion: . @PaulKrugman responded to readers commenting on his column "Good Luck to Republicans if Biden’s Family Plan Becomes Law."…

The fact that we don't have a well-established child care system — or a powerful child care industry lobby — means that the plan can be less intricate and less easily demagogued than health reform (except for those who believe that all good things are Communism) 4/

In fact, child care would in important ways be easier than health care reform. The big problem Obamacare had to confront was the existing crazy quilt of private insurance, which it tried to disturb as little as possible; this added a lot of complexity 3/

I'm being bombarded by claims that a national child care program is impossible — that there would be no way to police the use of the funds, that the administrative burden would be immense, etc. But many other rich countries already have such programs! 2/
